bacterial_categories.description: This broad group includes many common clinically significant bacteria. Testing for these organisms often involves a tiered approach for various antimicrobial agents.

pathogens.name: Escherichia coli
notes: Includes E. coli Enteroaggregative.
For isolates from the urinary tract, nitrofurantoin should be reported if susceptible.
Cefazolin is a surrogate for uncomplicated UTIs due to E. coli.

pathogens.name: Enterobacter cloacae complex
notes: Cefepime should be considered a Tier 1 agent for testing and/or reporting.

pathogens.name: Klebsiella sp.
notes: Includes K. oxytoca, K. pneumoniae, K. variicola, K. aerogenes, K. rhinoscleromatis, and K. ozaenae.
Cefepime is a Tier 1 agent for certain Klebsiella species.
Cefazolin is a surrogate for uncomplicated UTIs due to K. pneumoniae.

pathogens.name: Morganella morganii
notes: Cefepime is a Tier 1 agent for M. morganii.

pathogens.name: Citrobacter sp.
notes: Includes Citrobacter freundii and Citrobacter koseri.
Cefepime is a Tier 1 agent for C. freundii complex.

pathogens.name: Serratia marcescens
notes: Cefepime is a Tier 1 agent for S. marcescens.

pathogens.name: Proteus sp.
notes: Includes P. mirabilis, P. penneri, and P. vulgaris.
Cefazolin is a surrogate for uncomplicated UTIs due to P. mirabilis.

pathogens.name: Providencia sp.
notes: Includes P. stuartii, P. rettgeri, and P. alcalificiens.
Cefepime is a Tier 1 agent for Providencia spp.

bacterial_categories.description: Antimicrobial susceptibility testing results for these organisms are important for guiding treatment.

pathogens.name: Shigella sp.
notes: Routine susceptibility testing is not indicated; however, susceptibility testing is indicated for all Shigella isolates.
Ampicillin, a fluoroquinolone, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should be reported routinely.

pathogens.name: Salmonella sp.
notes: For non-typhoidal Salmonella spp., routine susceptibility testing is not indicated.
Susceptibility testing is indicated for typhoidal Salmonella (S. enterica ser. Typhi and S. enterica ser. Paratyphi A-C).
Azithromycin disk diffusion zone sizes and MIC data are limited for S. enterica ser. Typhi.

bacterial_categories.description: This organism can develop resistance during therapy, making susceptibility testing important.
Testing for Acinetobacter species is crucial due to potential multidrug resistance.
Testing for this complex often requires specific methods, as disk diffusion tests can be unreliable.
This organism is known for its intrinsic resistance to certain antibiotics.

pathogens.name: Stenotrophomonas maltophilia
notes: Levofloxacin and Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should not be used alone for antimicrobial therapy.

bacterial_categories.description: This category includes various Gram-negative bacilli. For some organisms in this group, MIC testing is preferred due to unreliable disk diffusion results.

pathogens.name: Vibrio spp.
notes: Includes V. cholerae, V. parahaemolyticus, V. vulnificus, V. alginolyticus, and V. damsela.

pathogens.name: Campylobacter spp.
notes: Includes C. jejuni, C. coli, and C. fetus.

pathogens.name: Aerococcus spp.
notes: Includes A. urinae and A. sanguinicola.

pathogens.name: Gemella spp.
notes: Includes G. mobillorum.

bacterial_categories.description: This group requires careful consideration for methicillin resistance and inducible clindamycin resistance.
category_notes: For staphylococci that are susceptible to clindamycin but resistant to erythromycin, testing for inducible clindamycin resistance (D-zone test) is required.

pathogens.name: Staphylococcus aureus
notes: Detection of methicillin (oxacillin) resistance (MRSA) is critical and can be done using cefoxitin or oxacillin.
For S. aureus with vancomycin MIC >= 8 µg/mL, further testing at a referral laboratory is recommended.

pathogens.name: Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus
notes: Includes S. haemolyticus, S. epidermidis, S. saprophyticus, S. lugdunensis, and others.
Detection of methicillin (oxacillin) resistance is important.

bacterial_categories.description: Susceptibility testing for enterococci often involves high-level aminoglycoside resistance (HLAR) testing.
category_notes: Routine reporting of organisms from the lower respiratory tract is not typically done for Enterococcus spp.

pathogens.name: Enterococcus faecium
notes: Ampicillin results can predict susceptibility to amoxicillin-clavulanate, ampicillin-sulbactam, and piperacillin-tazobactam for non-β-lactamase-producing enterococci.
The breakpoint for susceptible-dose dependent (SDD) is intended for serious infections.
Consultation with an infectious diseases specialist is recommended.
Vancomycin susceptibility testing should predict resistance for E. faecalis.

bacterial_categories.description: Beta-lactamase testing is crucial for determining ampicillin and amoxicillin resistance in these species.

pathogens.name: Haemophilus ducreyi
notes: Also known as Chancroid.
Susceptibility tests with antimicrobial agents are not routinely necessary for managing individual patients.

bacterial_categories.description: Susceptibility testing is recommended in cases of treatment failure.
Testing considerations for penicillin and cephalosporins vary based on the isolate's source (e.g., CSF vs. non-meningitis isolates).
This group includes clinically important pathogens like Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Strep) and Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Strep).
category_notes: For intrapartum prophylaxis for Group B Streptococcus in penicillin-allergic women at high risk for anaphylaxis, testing for clindamycin or vancomycin susceptibility may be needed.
If an isolate is susceptible to clindamycin but resistant to erythromycin, inducible clindamycin resistance (ICR) should be tested.

pathogens.name: Streptococcus pyogenes
notes: Includes Beta hemolytic Groups A, C, F, G Strep.

pathogens.name: Streptococcus agalactiae
notes: Also known as Group B Strep.

bacterial_categories.description: This group encompasses various species, some of which may require penicillin-aminoglycoside combination therapy.

pathogens.name: Abiotrophia spp.
notes: Formerly nutritionally variant streptococci, and are generally excluded from primary susceptibility testing tables as per CLSI guidance [4].

pathogens.name: Granulicatella spp.
notes: Formerly nutritionally variant streptococci, and are generally excluded from primary susceptibility testing tables as per CLSI guidance [4].

bacterial_categories.description: Specific safety precautions are recommended when performing AST for N. meningitidis due to the risk of laboratory-acquired infection.
category_notes: Prophylaxis for meningococcal case contacts is mentioned.
Breakpoints may not apply to therapy of patients with invasive meningococcal disease.

bacterial_categories.description: For anaerobes, specific testing methods and interpretive criteria are provided.

pathogens.name: Fusobacterium spp.
notes: Includes F. necrophorum and F. nucleatum.

pathogens.name: Bacteroides and Parabacteroides spp.
notes: Includes Bacteroides sp., Prevotella sp., and Bacteroides fragilis.

pathogens.name: Peptoniphilus sp. and Finegoldia sp.
notes: These organisms, along with Parvimonas spp., are often excluded from routine AST, though MIC breakpoints may be available elsewhere.

pathogens.name: Eggerthella lenta
notes: Formerly Eubacterium lentum.

uncategorized_pathogens.description: These bacteria are not specifically included in the routine antimicrobial susceptibility testing tables in the CLSI document, or AST is complex/not well-defined, and may require specialized testing or clinical consultation.

pathogens.name: Corynebacterium spp.
notes: Includes C. urealyticum, C. jeikeium, and C. diphtheriae.
